title: If mathematics is derived from logic, could mathematical platonism still be true? - Quora

response.answer_text: Mathematics is not derived from Logic. That would have been the dream of Gottlob Frege, dream that has failed. Mathematics needs Logic plus a bunch of non-logical axioms in order to work properly and to say anything interesting. The implication in your question, being based on a false premise, is valid. Though the conclusion is not necessarily true. You can find plenty of mathematicians and philosophers that do not agree with Platonism in the foundation of Mathematics.

First off, what is Platonism in mathematics? Platonism in the Philosophy of Mathematics. And what is an alternative? Constructivism (philosophy of mathematics) - Wikipedia. And you’ll note that mathematics is not derived from logic: Principia Mathematica - Volume One: Alfred North Whitehead, Bertrand Russell: 9781603864374: Amazon.com: Books (3 volumes). But it’s great to have someone ask a question about the philosophy of mathematics. And mathematics is not “true” or “false”.

Even if it could be proven that math is derived from logic, that would not make Platonism true. Laws of logic, like the axioms in math, are ideals that do not apply strictly to our reality. The concepts that we call numbers are purely imaginary and have no relation to anything in this world. Galileo’s belief that, all of nature is numbers, was an example of total self-deception.

Platonism is the belief that things can exist non-physically. So yes, it could still be true because logic is a system for judgement. Things can still exist non-physically unless there’s enough evidence to conclude, either logically or empirically, that it does not exist.
Mathematics is not derived from logic. The person who first demonstrated this to be true, Kurt Gödel, one of the outstanding mathematicians of the 20th century, happened to be a platonist.
Yes, although either they are somewhat less associated than need be, or the Godel incompleteness theorem indicates it is somewhat incomplete at best.
I am not an expert on the subject but my rudimentary understanding of mathematical platonism suggests that it is totally consistent with 21st century understanding of mathematical philosophy.
Without claiming to have specialised in this much, I suppose that Occam’s razor would cut away all those mathematical objects fairly easily if some logicism project demonstrated their superfluity.
